trans-unit.source: How to: Implement Role Based Access Control (RBAC) in a Claims-Aware ASP.NET Application Using WIF and ACS

trans-unit.target: Azure

trans-unit.source: How to: Implement Role Based Access Control (RBAC) in a Claims-Aware ASP.NET Application Using WIF and ACS
trans-unit.target: How to: Implement Role Based Access Control (RBAC) in a Claims-Aware ASP.NET Application Using WIF and ACS

trans-unit.source: Applies To
trans-unit.target: Applies To

trans-unit.source: Windows® Identity Foundation (WIF)
trans-unit.target: Windows® Identity Foundation (WIF)

trans-unit.source: ASP.NET
trans-unit.target: ASP.NET

trans-unit.source: Summary
trans-unit.target: Summary

trans-unit.source: This topic explains how to implement Role Based Access Control (RBAC) authorization in claims-aware ASP.NET web applications using WIF and <token>secondref_acs</token>.
trans-unit.target: This topic explains how to implement Role Based Access Control (RBAC) authorization in claims-aware ASP.NET web applications using WIF and <token>secondref_acs</token>.

trans-unit.target: Contents

trans-unit.source: Objectives
trans-unit.target: Objectives

trans-unit.source: Configure role claims using <token>secondref_acs</token>.
trans-unit.target: Configure role claims using <token>secondref_acs</token>.

trans-unit.source: Transform role claims using the ClaimsAuthenticationManager.
trans-unit.target: Transform role claims using the ClaimsAuthenticationManager.

trans-unit.source: Implement role-based access control checks using the <parameterReference>IsInRole</parameterReference> method and the PrinciaplPermission attributes.
trans-unit.target: Implement role-based access control checks using the <parameterReference>IsInRole</parameterReference> method and the PrinciaplPermission attributes.

trans-unit.source: Overview
trans-unit.target: Overview

trans-unit.source: RBAC is a widely adopted approach for restricting access in applications.
trans-unit.target: RBAC is a widely adopted approach for restricting access in applications.

trans-unit.source: In ASP.NET web applications, this approach is implemented using the <parameterReference>IsInRole</parameterReference> method, the <parameterReference>PrincipalPermission</parameterReference> attribute, or demands, which have been available since ASP.NET 1.0.
trans-unit.target: In ASP.NET web applications, this approach is implemented using the <parameterReference>IsInRole</parameterReference> method, the <parameterReference>PrincipalPermission</parameterReference> attribute, or demands, which have been available since ASP.NET 1.0.

trans-unit.source: You can use claims for authorization, thereby preserving well-established practices while using new technologies, such as WIF and <token>secondref_acs</token>.
trans-unit.target: You can use claims for authorization, thereby preserving well-established practices while using new technologies, such as WIF and <token>secondref_acs</token>.

trans-unit.source: You can download the WIF runtime and SDK here:
trans-unit.target: You can download the WIF runtime and SDK here:

trans-unit.source: Windows Identity Foundation Runtime
trans-unit.target: Windows Identity Foundation Runtime

trans-unit.source: Windows Identity Foundation SDK
trans-unit.target: Windows Identity Foundation SDK

trans-unit.source: Step 1 – Create a Simple Claims-Aware ASP.NET Web Application
trans-unit.target: Step 1 – Create a Simple Claims-Aware ASP.NET Web Application

trans-unit.source: This step shows you how to create a basic ASP.NET web application that will be used as a baseline for implementing RBAC.
trans-unit.target: This step shows you how to create a basic ASP.NET web application that will be used as a baseline for implementing RBAC.

trans-unit.source: To create a simple ASP.NET web application
trans-unit.target: To create a simple ASP.NET web application

trans-unit.source: Start Visual Studio with the "Run as administrator" option.
trans-unit.target: Start Visual Studio with the "Run as administrator" option.

trans-unit.source: This is required for WIF.
trans-unit.target: This is required for WIF.

trans-unit.source: Create a new ASP.NET Empty Web Application.
trans-unit.target: Create a new ASP.NET Empty Web Application.

trans-unit.source: Add the aspx web form, and then give it a name, for example, default.aspx.
trans-unit.target: Add the aspx web form, and then give it a name, for example, default.aspx.

trans-unit.source: Step 2 – Configure Role Claims in the ACS
trans-unit.target: Step 2 – Configure Role Claims in the ACS

trans-unit.source: This step shows you how to configure role claims on the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal using rule groups.
trans-unit.target: This step shows you how to configure role claims on the <token>secondref_acs</token> Management Portal using rule groups.

trans-unit.source: Refer to <link xlink:href="d0422d14-75f4-411b-aa47-4ceeccb7a33a" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">How to: Implement token transformation logic using Rules</link> for a complete step-by-step walkthrough.
trans-unit.target: Refer to <link xlink:href="d0422d14-75f4-411b-aa47-4ceeccb7a33a" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">How to: Implement token transformation logic using Rules</link> for a complete step-by-step walkthrough.

trans-unit.source: To configure role claims on the ACS Management Portal
trans-unit.target: To configure role claims on the ACS Management Portal

trans-unit.source: On the <ui>Edit Relying Party Application</ui> page, scroll down to the <ui>Rule Groups</ui> section, and then click the link of the desired group.
trans-unit.target: On the <ui>Edit Relying Party Application</ui> page, scroll down to the <ui>Rule Groups</ui> section, and then click the link of the desired group.

trans-unit.source: Make sure it is selected.
trans-unit.target: Make sure it is selected.

trans-unit.source: On the <ui>Edit Rule Group</ui> page, scroll down to the <ui>Rule</ui> section, and then click the <ui>Add Rule</ui> link.
trans-unit.target: On the <ui>Edit Rule Group</ui> page, scroll down to the <ui>Rule</ui> section, and then click the <ui>Add Rule</ui> link.

trans-unit.source: On the <ui>Add Claim Rule</ui> page, scroll down to the <ui>Output claim type</ui> section, click the <ui>Select type</ui> radio button, and then choose the following claim type.
trans-unit.target: On the <ui>Add Claim Rule</ui> page, scroll down to the <ui>Output claim type</ui> section, click the <ui>Select type</ui> radio button, and then choose the following claim type.

trans-unit.source:
In the Output claim value section, click Enter value, and then enter the following text as a value in the text box:

 User
trans-unit.target:
In the Output claim value section, click Enter value, and then enter the following text as a value in the text box:

 User

trans-unit.source: Optionally, (recommended) add a description, and then click <ui>Save</ui>.
trans-unit.target: Optionally, (recommended) add a description, and then click <ui>Save</ui>.

trans-unit.source: You have just configured the User role claim that can be added to any token.
trans-unit.target: You have just configured the User role claim that can be added to any token.

trans-unit.source: The scenario could be different depending upon your requirements.
trans-unit.target: The scenario could be different depending upon your requirements.

trans-unit.source: For more information about configuring more complex rules, see <link xlink:href="d0422d14-75f4-411b-aa47-4ceeccb7a33a" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">How to: Implement token transformation logic using Rules</link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about configuring more complex rules, see <link xlink:href="d0422d14-75f4-411b-aa47-4ceeccb7a33a" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">How to: Implement token transformation logic using Rules</link>.

trans-unit.source: Step 3 – Implement Role Checks in an ASP.NET Web Application
trans-unit.target: Step 3 – Implement Role Checks in an ASP.NET Web Application

trans-unit.source: This step shows how to implement RBAC.
trans-unit.target: This step shows how to implement RBAC.

trans-unit.source: To implement RBAC in an ASP.NET web page
trans-unit.target: To implement RBAC in an ASP.NET web page

trans-unit.source: Add a reference to the Microsoft.IdentityModel assembly.
trans-unit.target: Add a reference to the Microsoft.IdentityModel assembly.

trans-unit.source: Open the code behind default.aspx.cs.
trans-unit.target: Open the code behind default.aspx.cs.

trans-unit.source: Add the following, using declarations.
trans-unit.target: Add the following, using declarations.

trans-unit.source: Decorate the Page_Load event handler with the following security demand.
trans-unit.target: Decorate the Page_Load event handler with the following security demand.

trans-unit.source: This attribute will check if to see if the current user is in the User role.
trans-unit.target: This attribute will check if to see if the current user is in the User role.

trans-unit.source: If not, an exception will be thrown.
trans-unit.target: If not, an exception will be thrown.

trans-unit.source: Add the following code to the body of Page_Load event handler.
trans-unit.target: Add the following code to the body of Page_Load event handler.

trans-unit.source: This is exactly the same as the demand expressed in the code.
trans-unit.target: This is exactly the same as the demand expressed in the code.

trans-unit.source: Add the following code to the body of Page_Load event.
trans-unit.target: Add the following code to the body of Page_Load event.

trans-unit.source: As opposed to the previous code, this code does not throw an exception.
trans-unit.target: As opposed to the previous code, this code does not throw an exception.

trans-unit.source: Instead, IsInRole returns Boolean indicating whether the current user has the specified role.
trans-unit.target: Instead, IsInRole returns Boolean indicating whether the current user has the specified role.

trans-unit.source: The completed code should look similar to the following.
trans-unit.target: The completed code should look similar to the following.

trans-unit.source: Step 4 – Implement a Claims Transformation Using a Custom ClaimsAuthenticationManager
trans-unit.target: Step 4 – Implement a Claims Transformation Using a Custom ClaimsAuthenticationManager

trans-unit.source: This is an optional step.
trans-unit.target: This is an optional step.

trans-unit.source: This step shows how to transform claims using the ClaimsAuthenticationManager, which is part of the WIF pipeline that runs within the context of the ASP.NET application, as opposed to the claims transformation rules that run on <token>secondref_acs</token> as described in <link xlink:href="55b7634e-2ab7-4003-a1ab-cc8695829af2#BKMK_3" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Step 2 – Configure Role Claims in the ACS</link>.
trans-unit.target: This step shows how to transform claims using the ClaimsAuthenticationManager, which is part of the WIF pipeline that runs within the context of the ASP.NET application, as opposed to the claims transformation rules that run on <token>secondref_acs</token> as described in <link xlink:href="55b7634e-2ab7-4003-a1ab-cc8695829af2#BKMK_3" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Step 2 – Configure Role Claims in the ACS</link>.

trans-unit.source: To implement the claims transformation using a custom ClaimsAuthenticationManager
trans-unit.target: To implement the claims transformation using a custom ClaimsAuthenticationManager

trans-unit.source: Add the <ui>Class Library</ui> project to the Visual Studio Solution, and then give it a name, for example, MyClaimsTransformationModule.
trans-unit.target: Add the <ui>Class Library</ui> project to the Visual Studio Solution, and then give it a name, for example, MyClaimsTransformationModule.

trans-unit.source: Add a reference to the <ui>Microsoft.IdentityModel</ui> assembly.
trans-unit.target: Add a reference to the <ui>Microsoft.IdentityModel</ui> assembly.

trans-unit.source: Add a reference to the <ui>System.IdentityModel</ui> assembly.
trans-unit.target: Add a reference to the <ui>System.IdentityModel</ui> assembly.

trans-unit.source: Create a new class, and then give it a name, for example, ClaimsTransformationModule.
trans-unit.target: Create a new class, and then give it a name, for example, ClaimsTransformationModule.

trans-unit.source: Add the following declarations to the class.
trans-unit.target: Add the following declarations to the class.

trans-unit.source: Derive the class from the <ui>ClaimsAuthenticationManager</ui> type.
trans-unit.target: Derive the class from the <ui>ClaimsAuthenticationManager</ui> type.

trans-unit.source: Override its <ui>Authenticate</ui> method (this is where claims transformation will take place).
trans-unit.target: Override its <ui>Authenticate</ui> method (this is where claims transformation will take place).

trans-unit.source: Your code for the <ui>Authenticate</ui> method can be based on the following.
trans-unit.target: Your code for the <ui>Authenticate</ui> method can be based on the following.

trans-unit.source: Switch to the ASP.NET application and configure your custom ClaimsAuthenticationManager in its web.config.
trans-unit.target: Switch to the ASP.NET application and configure your custom ClaimsAuthenticationManager in its web.config.

trans-unit.source: Make sure the new assembly you created can be found by the application; the simplest way is to place it in the application’s bin folder.
trans-unit.target: Make sure the new assembly you created can be found by the application; the simplest way is to place it in the application’s bin folder.

trans-unit.source: Step 5 – Test Your Work
trans-unit.target: Step 5 – Test Your Work

trans-unit.source: This step shows how to validate that the solution works.
trans-unit.target: This step shows how to validate that the solution works.

trans-unit.source: To test your solution, press the F5 button.
trans-unit.target: To test your solution, press the F5 button.

trans-unit.source: Your ASP.NET web application should run in debug mode (you can add breakpoints to verify the code execution within Visual Studio).
trans-unit.target: Your ASP.NET web application should run in debug mode (you can add breakpoints to verify the code execution within Visual Studio).

trans-unit.source: First, you should be taken to the authentication page of the identity provider that was configured for federation.
trans-unit.target: First, you should be taken to the authentication page of the identity provider that was configured for federation.

trans-unit.source: After the authentication has completed, you should be redirected back to the Default.aspx page without an exception being thrown, which means that all of the security demands for the User role were satisfied.
trans-unit.target: After the authentication has completed, you should be redirected back to the Default.aspx page without an exception being thrown, which means that all of the security demands for the User role were satisfied.
